newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIA FUEL OIL - FIRM ON FRESH BUYING SUPPORT.
newsitem.headline: ASIA FUEL OIL - FIRM ON FRESH BUYING SUPPORT.

text.p: The Singapore high sulphur fuel oil market edged up on Wednesday as a new buyer emerged on the physical market amid rising swap values, traders said.
The Dutch trader is the third buyer to emerge this week for fuel oil amid tight supplies.
Over the past week, a Singapore trader and a Middle East trader have bought 20,000-tonne cargoes at $103.50 and $102.50 per tonne, respectively, on a free-on-board basis.
The Dutch trader's bid at $103.50 on Wednesday failed to entice any selling interest as supplies in Singapore, especially for prompt lifting are tight.

The tightness was clearly reflected in the bunker market where supplies for lifting over the next few days are priced at up to $5.00 per tonne above the usual products that are sold for delivery 7-10 days out.

Bunker prices have also risen in tandem with the stronger cargo prices with 380-cst for delivery in a week's time sold at $107.00 and 180-cst for similar timing sold at $110.50, bunker suppliers said.
"The latest physical buying has spooked the market and everyone's buying because they think the market is going to be bidded up over the next few days," one trader said.

September fuel oil was last quoted at $104.00/$105.00 per tonne, up from Tuesday's $103.50/$104.50, brokers said. It traded earlier in the day at $104.25 and $104.50 compared to Tuesday's traded intra-day high of $103.75, they said.
Traders said the latest price increase was due to the emergence of more than one buyer in the physical market with more buyers seen in the swaps market.
Swaps buyers included Chinese trading companies, Japanese trading houses and Singapore traders, brokers said.
Buying from Chinese traders in the swaps market for September and October lots has also fuelled speculation that China will re-enter the market to buy physical cargoes.
China is currently bidding for physical cargoes at about $7.50-$8.00 per tonne above Singapore spot prices on a cost-and-freight south China basis.
(Prices in dollars per tonne, unless stated)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
*Dollars per barrel
-- Email: singapore.newsroom@reuters.com
